bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: David Kimberly (1785-1861), a merchant, entered the New York City business of his uncle, Gideon Kimberly, in 1800, and became a partner in 1813. In 1839, David Kimberly was also a creditor who held the notes for several Southern cotton growers. Both David and Gideon Kimberly resided in Brooklyn.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains deeds, bonds, and letters spanning the period 1788 to 1845. Included are 46 letters to creditor David Kimberly dating from 1839 and 1845, most from several Southern cotton growers asking for more time to pay debts due to a poor cotton crop. There are also five bankruptcy notices to David Kimberly dating from 1841 to 1842; four legal documents of the estate of Gideon Kimberly dating from 1819 to 1821; one letter from Amos Kimberly to his cousin, dated 1833; two deeds from 1788 and 1796; and one bond from 1802.
